data.title: No I.D.
data.meta_description: Explore the Red Bull Music Academy archive, tracing the global music institutionâs more than 20-year history
data.text:
Andrew Barber

I would like to bring to the stage No I.D. [applause] Hello again.

No I.D.

Once again.

Andrew Barber

Once again. Always a pleasure to sit down with you, happy to have you back in Chicago.

No I.D.

Happy to be here.

Andrew Barber

You doing alright with the weather?

No I.D.

Itâs cold.

Andrew Barber

Shell shocked a little bit?

No I.D.

Itâs cold.

Andrew Barber

So, you know, youâve had an incredible career as a rapper, a producer, an executive, an A&R, youâve really run the gamut of things that youâve done in the music business. Some people might say youâre the godfather of Chicago hip-hop but Iâll let you decide that or not. But tonight I just want to talk about your history and how you got to where you are today. So letâs start from the beginning. Hip-hop in Chicago, how did you get into it?

No I.D.

Well... the funny thing about it is for me it really starts with house music. It doesnât really start with hip-hop and I was gonna talk about that but letâsâ¦

Andrew Barber

Yeah.

No I.D.

Because you said the beginning, thatâs whyâ¦

Andrew Barber

Right.

No I.D.

So, alright letâs skip to hip-hop. Common, Iâve known him since we were nine, ten years old; used to play basketball together. Life, you know. Childhood friend, brother, and he was the one that would bring the hip-hop around. He had a cousin who passed away named Ajile, from Cincinnati, who used to influence us to get these tapes, and that led us to listening to WHPK which was the premier hip-hop radio station for us back then. Chilly Q and JB Chill, a lot of other names that you young people might not know.

But it was a foreign element to us because it was a house music city, period. Thatâs all we went to, house parties. I did house music, and growing up on the south side, a lot of things we got into were to stay out of trouble. [We could] be creative and be active in a way that would keep us on the straight and narrow. And in comes this thing called hip-hop. There was no scene, there was no industry, there was no thought of a deal, there was no money. It was literally like, âHmm, letâs try that.â And [that led] to break dancing and making beats and rapping, and making these little tapes, and performing them in different places. But that was my introduction into hip-hop and it probably wasnât until I heard Paid in Full or Criminal Minded that I was like, âI want to do this, actually. I want to do it.â

Andrew Barber

And so were you hearing those records on WHPK?

No I.D.

Yeah, and then after a while we just started finding the tapes. So we would just go try and find a new hip-hop album that would come out, and it was only certain stores that would have them and you had to just kind of find your way to it. So it was either trying to get someone from New York to send a tape back, so you can learn what those new songs were, what was being played. And then try and find who made it, and buy the tape, and then we would play basketball in the backyard, listen to the rap tapes.

Andrew Barber

And how big of a stronghold did house music have? Were you considered a complete outsider?

No I.D.

Absolutely. It was rare that you would hear a rap record at a party and it definitely wasnât like [throws hands in the air] It was more like, âWhat are we supposed to do to this? We donât even know what that is.â [laughter] Then another good friend that grew up with us was Twilite Tone. Him and Reggieknow, they formed a crew, and they would start throwing these hip-hop parties. And I think that was the first, for me. I know there were things that happened before me and my generation that definitely deserve recognition but for me that was the first place that I could go to and see a hip-hop party. And definitely, me being from the further south side, I had to make a journey to even get to that.

Andrew Barber

Because those guys were in Hyde Park, right?

No I.D.

They were in Hyde Park.

Andrew Barber

So that was like the Dem Dare crew?

No I.D.

Yes.

Andrew Barber

And you guys were the 87thâ¦

No I.D.

Yeah.

Andrew Barber

Street Crew?

No I.D.

Yeah, be careful how you say that. [laughs]

Andrew Barber

Sorry. So, the UACâ¦

No I.D.

It means something different.

Andrew Barber

OK, OK, my bad. So were you guys known as the UAC at that time? UnAmerican Caravan. Or was that later when you joined with Tone?

No I.D.

Yeah. I donât know that I was ever in it. I guess I was, but that was more Common, his intermediate circle when he really started rapping, because everybody needed a crew and that was the crew. And I guess I was just more of the producer in the equation thanâ¦ I guess I was in it though.

Andrew Barber

And did you guys mesh well with the kids from Hyde Park or was there a lot of tension there?

No I.D.

A lot of tension. A lot of tension, but we were nomads. We just kind of roamed around causing trouble, playing basketball, making music, just exploring. Young and dumb without guns really.

Andrew Barber

Right.

No I.D.

That was the blessing, that we didnât really have to face kind of what this generation does. We made a lot of mistakes but we didnât kill each other.

Andrew Barber

Right, and it wasnât posted on social media for the world to see.

No I.D.

Yeah.

Andrew Barber

So these parties that you were going to, where hip-hop was being played, at what point did it start to cross over and you noticed, âOK thereâs starting to become a scene here and these people are making music over here, theyâre doing it on this side of town,â etc, etc?

No I.D.

Iâm gonna say for me... Because Iâm going to try and touch on some things I havenât touched on, because Iâve done a lot of interviews. And I tell them... Iâm going to get into some why, a little more why this time, [more] than just what. For me I really kind of quit music at some point and went to college and I really didnât even have a thought anymore about making it, it being a scene.

I think I kind of ran a course withâ¦ because I was making house music and I think the business went so bad that I didnât have any faith in business anymore. And the side of business for hip-hop and the need of a scene was kind of irrelevant to me at that point. It was more just, âWhat am I going to do? I donât know what I want to do with my life,â and I ended up just going away to school which didnât go the way I wanted it to go.

Andrew Barber

So you go down there, and from what Iâve read or what weâve discussed in the past, you and Common were kind of sending music back and forth. Playing it for each other on the phone, answering machines and things like that, right?

No I.D.

Well no, actually how that went was, I went away to SIU [Southern Illinois University], which is a party school, and I lost my mind.

Andrew Barber

You had a little too much fun.

No I.D.

I did.

Andrew Barber

A little too much fun at SIU.

No I.D.

And actually the weird thing is I went for electrical engineering, something [where] youâre not supposed to lose your mind if you have any hopes of getting through it. But I had the wherewithal, I remember calling my mother like a year and a half in going, âI donât want to waste your money, I need to come home.â And now, serious now. So now I saw that Common was still going with the music and I was like, âHmm.â And now I could kind of see the seeds of a scene and different things.

Andrew Barber

So you were watching this happen from afar?

No I.D.

I watched it and I go, âI gotta get back in it. How am I gonna get back in it?â So I started making beats for me.

Andrew Barber

Because you rapped.

No I.D.

Because I rapped.

Andrew Barber

Yes. People here may not know that.

No I.D.

Yeah. So I was like, maybe I could be the third guy in the crew after, you know? And I just started making beats.

Andrew Barber

You could be like MC Ren. No disrespect but youâre not [Ice] Cube, youâre notâ¦

No I.D.

Yeah. Iâm just saying I gotta do something because my parents had a rule which served me well which was, âHave a job or get out or be in school. Take a pick.â So I remember the first real job I worked was telemarketing after I came home from college and I lasted a day and a half and thenâ¦

Andrew Barber

That fast, huh?

No I.D.

Yeah, and then my father, he has an electrical company and Regents Park was one of his clients. So he goes, âCome over here, put you to work,â and it was so bad. I mean... and the way the other people in the building were treating me. So I got about a week in and they had me doing stuff like scrubbing the pool with acid and cleaning the pipes on the roof, a hundred degrees and the steam in my face and I remember looking at the pipes, looking at the lake. âIâm doing music, right?â And thatâs when I decided, right? And I come down and I go, âI quit.â Iâm doing music. My fatherâs like, âWell what are you going to do?â Iâm like, âMusic.â Heâs like, âThatâs not a real thing.â

Andrew Barber

Very foreign now. Even now, itâsâ¦

No I.D.

Yeah.

Andrew Barber

But back then itâs likeâ¦

No I.D.

Yeah, youâre like, âCome on, man.â

Andrew Barber

In Chicago, like, âWhat do you mean?â

No I.D.

Heâs like, âWell you know what this means?â âI know.â I packed up my Aries K and I drove to Tallahassee where Common was still in school. I showed up, I saidâ¦

Andrew Barber

Did he know you were coming or did you just pull up?

No I.D.

Yeah, I told him. I said, âIâm on the way. Iâm pulling up. Make some space.â So in that time period is where I started. Itâs actually funny because a good friend of ours, Omaron, was back here with him and I remember the day when Tone, Omaron, me and Common... we used to go to his house in Hyde Park and just play stuff. And I remember I came and played some of my beats and they had finally got there, and he said some raps, and they finally got there.

And we kind of looked at each other and was like... he was like, âLet me get that one.â And that was the first time that I was really producing for him. And really most of the beats on Can I Borrow a Dollar? were my beats, for meâ¦

Andrew Barber

Or for yourself?

No I.D.

Yeah, he would be like, âLet me get that one, let me get that one.â And mind you I ended up getting like $200 a beat.

Andrew Barber

Itâs a pretty good deal. Itâs not bad.

No I.D.

It worked.

Andrew Barber

Yeah, it works. Itâs a placement, a placement worked. Did you do his demo, the one that eventually got toâ¦

No I.D.

That was some of the stuff that came about. So all in this time period is my level of desperate tempo sped up, and I was just making more and more and more music. And thatâs when I started leaving them messages on the machine and playing beats, anything just to get something going because it didnât look good. It did not look good.

Andrew Barber

It didnât look good but then things started happening.

No I.D.

Things started happening and whatever that means. It really didnât, but it did. He got a deal, which was an indie deal, the irony of that in 2018 when people are now fighting for independence. We started in an indie deal, because thatâs what hip-hop was. It was indie deals.

Andrew Barber

It was through Relativity.

No I.D.

Relativity.

Andrew Barber

Before they were picked up byâ¦

No I.D.

Now mind you, OK, we put a record out. It wasnât like [cheers], it was still like, âYeah, thatâs cool.â And I remember two specific things that happened. We went and opened up for [Uncle] Luke at FAMU [laughter] and Iâm DJingâ¦

Andrew Barber

That is apples and oranges right there.

No I.D.

Oh man, and weâre doing these records, âTake It Easy,â and the pennies start flying and Iâm like... [laughter]

Andrew Barber

So youâre ducking loose change onstage. Not panties, pennies.

No I.D.

Yes. Penny for my thoughts. So Iâm like, âLetâs wrap it up.â

Andrew Barber

Were you DJing?

No I.D.

Yeah, I actually had the SP-1200s up there and I was actually doing music live.

Andrew Barber

So Tone would DJ and you wouldâ¦

No I.D.

No, he wasnât even DJing then, he was hype man.

Andrew Barber

OK.

No I.D.

So he was actually performing. And then we left there, and we went and opened up for KRS-One and we ended up having fun. I love KRS-One. Heâs rapping and weâre throwing the sampler tapes out and the sampler tapes are coming right back. [laughter]

Andrew Barber

And are you in New York opening up for him or is this here, local?

No I.D.

New York. Iâm like, âMan. We ainât there yet.â

Andrew Barber

Not there yet.

No I.D.

Weâre not there yet.

Andrew Barber

Youâre not there yet, OK.

No I.D.

And it wasnât really âtil Resurrection that things turned around.

Andrew Barber

From the outside looking in as a young fan, Iâm seeing the videos on Rap City, Iâm seeing the videos on Yo! MTV Raps, so to the outside world it looks like youâre on. And OK, these are rap stars.

No I.D.

Welcome to the industry. It looks different than it is. We knew we were going out; we were touching the people. So we knew when people really were in and when they werenât. Just because it got played that donât mean people liked it or respected it to be honest. But it was baby steps, and a lot of times people donât understand until you really...

Your environment can create something really special, but it could be multiplied when you go around the world and you see more. Thatâs when you can expand that thing; and sometimes we donât ever get to that point, because we donât know how to get past that tipping point that allows us to move around and journey, and see different environments, and learn other stories. And kind of take that and come back and apply it differently.

Andrew Barber

Thatâs the thing that can hinder a lot of artists, people donât want to move around, go do that type of thing.

No I.D.

Absolutely.

Andrew Barber

You got to really want it.

No I.D.

Yeah and I always say this, music is the one, not the one thing â thereâs a few things â but one of the things that a lot of people just try and do with no previous education, no proper guidance or mentorshipâ¦

Andrew Barber

You donât need it to get in the business, right?

No I.D.

You just wake up one day and ... Iâll do music. Iâm a manager. I produce. I got Fruity Loops. It was free, I downloaded it. And thatâs it and you know thereâs no other real profession in this world where you just wake up and do it and say youâre doing it.

Andrew Barber

Now itâs even easier. Thereâs no barrier of entry anymore.

No I.D.

No, you could just do anything and put it out and buy some views.

Andrew Barber

Right. Itâs that easy.

No I.D.

Everywhere I look. Buy followers.

Andrew Barber

But you guys had to actuallyâ¦

No I.D.

Yes. We had to go through all of this all the time, and it had to bear fruit in a real way otherwise it did not exist. It just didnât exist. Thereâs a lot of things that were played back then that we donât talk about and those people donât have careers. They donât, you know. And we supposed to pick something thatâs supposed to feed our families and fulfill us but thatâs not always the case with the paths that we choose. And when you take three steps back again, what made us think that we could just do it anyway?

Thatâs something that motivational people [say]â¦ âDo it, you can do anything.â But there is a thing called education, and the positive person goes, educate yourself and then you can... and so Iâm right in between the middle there. Iâm seeking information. I donât have to go to a specific building and pay to learn. Itâs 2018, the information is available. You can seek information, guidance, and I guess my point is that when I look back I can see the growth between demo, Can I Borrow A Dollar?, Resurrection. We began to educate ourselves. We met people, we learned more. I learned what I was doing, I wasnât guessing. I was applying what I had as the kid that grew up, [whose] father played jazz in the house, always heard it. Loved music, DJed, played house music, understood tempos and edits and remixes, and then got into hip-hop and understood those elements.

But then as I traveled I began to understand how people were making records that were working, and I was no longer guessing. And I was mixing that with what I liked, and then it kind of turned into my style.

Andrew Barber

Right. And did you record Can I Borrow a Dollar? in Chicago or did you have to go to New York andâ¦

No I.D.

New York.

Andrew Barber

So everything at the time, you guys were going to New York to record everything?

No I.D.

And the funniest thing is I used the SP-1200 which only had 10 seconds of sampling time. A lot of records, we would need 20 seconds, so I had to make part of the beat on here and then take the disc out and make another part. And I would never even hear it together until it was laid.

So when we went to do this album we would go and we got like, âAlright weâre doing 13 songs and we got ten days,â and we never heard it all together ever before that.

Andrew Barber

Wow. You would have to go literally lock in for ten days.

No I.D.

Yeah.

Andrew Barber

Writerâs block be damned, creative blocksâ¦

No I.D.

No, you gotta have the songs before you get there. Not writing.

Andrew Barber

OK.

No I.D.

Not much writing in there. Listen, âTen days, have your raps and you have these beats, go.â

Andrew Barber

So you never heard them, there was no pre-production before that though?

No I.D.

No.

Andrew Barber

OK.

No I.D.

Thatâs just what it was and we had to imagine the result.

Andrew Barber

So the first album comes out, doesnât sell that well but it doesnât matter. You get another shot. How hard was it to get another shot back then?

No I.D.

$200 a beat.

Andrew Barber

The budget was small.

No I.D.

The deal mightâve been $50,000.

Andrew Barber

So they give you another chance.

No I.D.

Yeah.

Andrew Barber

And this becomes the Resurrection.

No I.D.

Well, because of the âSoul By The Poundâ remix.

Andrew Barber

So thatâs what did it?

No I.D.

Thatâs what kind of made people go, âAh, OK, give them a shot.â

Andrew Barber

OK, because they liked that record. That had the most traction of any.

No I.D.

Yeah, that was like, OK. Then I got a couple calls. âHey man, that was pretty good.â Before, it was like, âYeah man, doing your little rap thing huh? Keep it up.â [laughter]

Andrew Barber

And so you guys are going to New York, youâre traveling around, youâre these Chicago kids in New York and are you gettingâ¦ thereâs no rap in Chicago, Iâm sure theyâre probably kind of treating you guys a little different. Were you getting respect?

No I.D.

Not at first but the first people we met was the Beatnuts, Chi-Ali, and then we met Q-Tip.

Andrew Barber

Youâre like Native Tongues and likeâ¦

No I.D.

Yeah. Fat Joe, Pun before Pun was signed. So in this circle where... back then, digging in the crates was a thing, so I was a DJ. So Iâd be like, âHey back in Chicagoâs a lot of records, do you want to give me some names? Iâll go get some stuff for you,â which is how I really started to learn how to do that specific art of just finding obscure music to sample, which broadened my ear, made me more educated. I learned about reading about the personnel on records. It just expanded my horizons in a way that I never wouldâve just expanded it on my own.

Andrew Barber

So this is â94 which is maybe the most competitive year in rap music history.

No I.D.

Yeah.

Andrew Barber

Yeah.

No I.D.

I call it the platinum era.

Andrew Barber

Right.

No I.D.

The golden era was before the platinum era.

Andrew Barber

This is the platinum era?

No I.D.

Yeah.

Andrew Barber

Where people are really going platinum.

No I.D.

Yeah. Drug deals are accepted too. Before that they werenât.

Andrew Barber

Right. So youâre competing with the likes of Biggie, competing with... Nas drops in â94, Wu-Tangâs doing their thing in â94, Craig Mack. Itâs a lot of stuff happening. Murder Was The Case soundtrack. That album drops in the fall of â94, right? Fourth quarter, yeah?

No I.D.

Yes.

Andrew Barber

So all the big dogs are out.

No I.D.

Yeah. Not to mention Chronic is still tearing up the atmosphere. Doggystyle. So imagine weâre like, âTake It Easyâ and all of thatâs happening. Weâre like, âOh man.â

Andrew Barber

And itâs a big change from Can I Borrow a Dollar? to Resurrection. Itâs a completely different sound.

No I.D.

Yes.

Andrew Barber

Common was kind of rapping almost like a Das EFX. He had a fast rap. This was a totally different sound.

No I.D.

Yeah, this was like, âHey man weâre gonna get serious. Stop playing around. Iâm not playing, youâre not playing, letâs go.â

Andrew Barber

So what changed the mindset? Is it because you saw...

No I.D.

Yeah, we traveled. We saw the pennies was flying, everything. We were like, âHey man weâre gonna be back at home.â

Andrew Barber

Right.

No I.D.

Letâs turn up.

Andrew Barber

Letâs not go back home empty handed.

No I.D.

Weâre not going home.

Andrew Barber

Weâre gonna go home with a W.

No I.D.

Yes. 100%. Without a doubt. So now it was like pitbull mentality. It was no longer, we just want to be respected, it was more like, âUh-uh, yâall not gonna do this to us, make us look crazy out here, no.â

Andrew Barber

And so that album [Resurrection] happens. âI Used to Love H.E.R.â Looking back itâs a classic album, undisputed, but at the time when it dropped how did you feel it was received? Were you disappointed? Because I read somewhere it sold like 2,000 copies in the first week. I donât know if thatâs true or not but.

No I.D.

Yeah, thatâs true. At that point I donât even know that we even were conscious of first week sales like that. I think we were still just more like, âOh man, weâre getting good reviews. Oh man, certain people are calling us up saying they like it, people that we respect.â I think that was probably more important to us, because again I donât think we had any concept of... Puff and Big hadnât threw the rollies in the sky just yet.

Andrew Barber

It wasnât quite there yet.

No I.D.

Yeah, the Cristal didnât really... it wasnât in our club as a purchasable option.

Andrew Barber

It was still about respect, having skills, having dope beats, being able to find the obscure samples, having the best beats, having the best run. Thatâs what it was then.

No I.D.

Yeah. It was just a different time period, thatâs what Iâm also trying to say. Not making light of any of the eras. I hadnât even looked at myself as a producer. I look at us like a group, like Gangstarr or whatever, Pete Rock and CL Smooth. We just wanted to be accepted and appreciated.

Andrew Barber

And once that happens, what was the climate like in the city? So you come back home, you come back to Chicago, how were you guys treated when you come back? Because I feel like now thereâs a scene happening.

No I.D.

Yeah, and then across town you got Crucial Conflict and Do or Die, and Twista, theyâre selling records. Weâre like, âHey, woah.â

Andrew Barber

Weâve never talked about this and this is something Iâve always wanted to ask you.

No I.D.

No, thatâs good. We never talkedâ¦

Andrew Barber

Yeah, we havenât talked about this before.

No I.D.

Alright, good. Letâs go.

Andrew Barber

Weâre not just going through the motions.

No I.D.

Letâs go.

Andrew Barber

So, what is that like? You have this critically acclaimed album, everybody loves it, the videoâs getting heavy rotation, Rap City, everybody loves âI Used To Love H.E.R,â the âResurrectionâ videoâs crazy. But then you come back to Chicago and itâs like, OK well weâre not selling a ton of records. But across town, even though Traxster is from the south side heâs producing for Do or Die who have a smash hit with âPo Pimp.â They rebrand Twista from a gimmick rapper to OK, this dudeâs for real and then you got Crucial Conflict. Theyâre going gold and platinum.

No I.D.

Yes.

Andrew Barber

What are you feeling?

No I.D.

I think it was such an artistically different expression that we had not accepted that as a competition. We kind of just looked at it like, âOh wow, that can happen,â more than, âWait a minute, why is that happening?â The funny thing is, I joke with Traxster about how it was this unspoken tension between us for years and it wasnât until we werenât in Chicago that we were like, âHey man, hey. Whatâs up?â

Andrew Barber

The No I.D. versus Traxster stuff. I remember that.

No I.D.

Yeah. It wasnât something that really bothered us. It wasnât something that reallyâ¦ had it been the type of music we were making and it was doing those numbers, we probably wouldâve felt a way. But I think we just looked at it like, âOh OK.â

Andrew Barber

It was such a different sound.

No I.D.

Yeah, it was more like, âWow thatâs possible for someone here.â And I think thatâs what you get going into One Day Itâll All Make Sense and itâs like, âOK, letâs expand. Letâs work with Erykah Badu, letâs work with Lauryn Hill, letâs work with Cee Lo, letâs work with The Roots, letâs work withâ¦ It was no longer about letâs just go in the basement and make some music. Now itâs like letâs try and win. Not just be credible.

Andrew Barber

Right. Then thatâs when the commercial aspirations began.

No I.D.

Yes.

Andrew Barber

But nothing was a super reach.

No I.D.

No. It was still within the wheelhouse.

Andrew Barber

Yeah, right.

No I.D.
